  • Feb 15, 2015

    Welcome to Jekyll!

    You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

    To add new posts, simply add a file in the _posts directory that follows the convention YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext and includes the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

    Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

    def print_hi(name)
  puts "Hi, #{name}"
end
print_hi('Tom')
#=> prints 'Hi, Tom' to STDOUT.

    Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll’s dedicated Help repository.

  • Apr 3, 2012

    Doing stuff, and final 365 rejects

    Now I've exhausted the stash of outtakes from last year, I'm considering starting another 365 project soon. Just have to make sure I enjoy it more this time and don't beat myself up so much about it. Some days will just be rubbish.

    Going to do some work on the site soon too. That's all I've decided about that at the moment.

  • Mar 25, 2012

    Allergy visit

    Cute cats aside, yesterday was a bit shit. Turns out Steph is allergic to Siberian cats, which are probably the most hypoallergenic breed in the world. It basically puts an end to our hopes of eventually getting a cat.

    Still, there are loads of hypoallergenic dog breeds...

  • Jan 2, 2012

    365: Didn't miscount, then

    I'm very pleased the project is over. As much fun as it was (and it really was, despite some moaning I may have done on here), in the last couple of months it sometimes felt less like fun and more like a chore. Still, I'm really glad I did it. I'm definitely going to keep taking photos and I'll probably continue to take my camera everywhere with me. I might even post some of the results on here, probably a lot less frequently than I did in 2011, though.

    Anyway, below are some more photos I took on day 365.

    Still, a fun Sunday morning at the frozen Arrow Valley Lake.

  • Sep 5, 2011

    238: Luminarium Mirazozo

    I went into the Luminarium Mirazozo in George Square to shelter from the rain. It's a big walk-in sculpture lit with natural light from the outside. It's pretty peaceful in there, but it's also quite dark, which means ISO 800, which means some very noisy photos.

  • Aug 16, 2011

    226: Coventry parkour

    There's something I really love about walking around with a camera, trying to find stuff to take photos of. It can lead to some cool, spontaneous meetings with people I wouldn't have otherwise come across.

    Tudor and Payam are two of the friendliest people I've met in a while and following them around Coventry was a good way to spend a Sunday afternoon. That town seems like the perfect place for parkour.

    Kind of fucked up the processing of some of these - I'm using Fireworks for PC this week for a couple of stupid reasons, and I can't get it to do what I want most of the time. I took some other photos around Coventry that I might post a bit later, but definitely not until I'm back on Aperture.

  • Aug 14, 2011

    223-225

    I'm really enjoying taking photos at the moment. Not sure about some of the results, but I'm having fun trying. That's the important thing, right?

    Had a few drinks and watched a Stewart Lee DVD on Friday night, then remembered I hadn't taken any photos.

  • Aug 10, 2011

    If you think there are too many photos here, bear in mind I did take 500. This could have been so much worse.

  • Jul 26, 2011

    201: John

    I've been thinking about doing a 100 Strangers project for a little while, as a way to get me more confident in both taking pictures of people and also approaching them to ask if I can do it in the first place.

    John asking me for some spare change seemed like a good opportunity to start (he approached me after all), and in the end he was happy for me to take his picture.

  • Jul 12, 2011

    192/365: .flies:hover

    I've been trying for over a week to get some pictures of these buggers. They recently turned up in our garden but they move so quickly it's been very hard to get anything decent. On Monday, though, I think I got the best I'm going to be able to, at least for now. I might try again some other time, but for now I'm fairly happy with these.

    The ones below are some of my attempts from earlier in the week.

  • Jul 12, 2011

    190 & 191/365

    This was taken at a talent show just down the road from the house. I quite like it, but I'm beginning to question the black & white.

    And this one was in the car park of Touchwood Shopping Centre in Solihull. It looked quite cool on my Mac Mini and didn't need any editing, but seeing it on my Macbook makes me wish it wasn't so dark.

  • Jul 9, 2011

    178-182/365: Last week

    After a few positive comments from people I went into last week with a bit more confidence about taking photos. Well, enough for me to actually enjoy doing it, which is way better than the last few weeks.

    Took Steph and her sister to a concert at Villa Park on Tuesday. While I was driving around waiting for it to finish I spotted this through some gates:

    It was a scrap yard, in which the shells of cars were stacked on top of one-another, with their engines and other parts scattered around nearby. I went back on Wednesday to get a shot and luckily somebody actually let me in, which is how I managed to get close enough to get the photo above. My confidence boost really paid off here; a few months ago there's no way I'd have had the guts to ask a (rather scary-looking) stranger to let me into his premises.

  • Jul 5, 2011

    177/365: Patience

    It's a good job I had a free afternoon.

  • Jul 5, 2011

    176/365: Fresh Air 2011

    Thanks to one of my Flickr contacts I was made aware of Fresh Air 2011, a sculpture exhibition held in a tiny village in the Cotswolds. I wasn't going to go, feeling disillusioned with my photos and all, but I'm glad I did in the end.

    Today was mostly about reflections, it seems.

  • Jul 4, 2011

    Old holiday snaps: Kenya

    Some photos from our trip to Kenya in Autumn 2009. Can't remember which ones were taken by me and which are Steph's, so I'll take credit for them all.

    These were taken with our old Canon Powershot, probably on Auto mode, before I knew anything about cameras and stuff. Despite that, I'm quite pleased with some of the results.

    I only like this bottom one because it looks like he's got arms.

  • Jun 30, 2011

    162/365: Flyin' Ryan

    This is Flyin' Ryan, a motorcycle stunt man, at a show he was doing in Redditch. My Dad had lent me his telephoto lens, which turned out to be quite useful because they had set up safety barriers really far away from the ramp. It wasn't easy, partially because the lens is manual focus only, but I got these 2 that I was quite pleased with.

    More Brighton

    So yeah, as we expected, Brighton is ace. We spent most of our time there either shopping or eating. If you like good vegetarian food, Brighton's definitely the place to go.

    I've decided to post slightly bigger photos from now on. I'm hoping they'll distract from the fact that I'm not writing anything interesting.

  • Jun 13, 2011

    158/365: Weird bug thing

  • Jun 7, 2011

    145-148/365: Brighton

    We went to Brighton for a few days last week, and got lots of photos, some of which I'm quite pleased with.

  • May 14, 2011

    Photos for Kulturplatz

    After a request from a guy on a Radiohead forum, last week I took lots of pictures of the King of Limbs newspaper album for a short report he was producing for Swiss TV. The brief was to take photos of the individual elements (vinyl, CD, artwork and newspaper) from above. Nothing fancy... i.e. not slanted; no angles, I believe were his words.

    Anyway, it has now been on TV and, if you want, you can watch it here. The photos are mostly near the start and near the end. I had to take them outside to take advantage of the evening light, so you'll notice our paving stones in some of the shots. I kind of assumed he'd crop those out, but what the hell.

  • Apr 26, 2011

    114/365: Photowalk with Jasper

    Spent Sunday afternoon with Jasper on a photowalk around some of the less trodden parts of Birmingham. He knows loads about photography and it was great to talk about that stuff and get advice from him. He's also really good at spotting cool photo opportunities, which you'll notice if you read his blog. Which you should.

    As is the norm when I post more than one, the top one is my photo of the day. I'm quite pleased with them all, but I chose that one because I think it'll look the best as a thumbnail next to the rest of them.

    Have you subscribed to Jasper's RSS feed yet? Why the fuck not?

  • Apr 22, 2011

    105/365: Decisions

    I've come to the realisation that I'm not great at judging whether my photos are good or not. This becomes difficult when I get more than one that I'm happy with and I don't know which one to choose for my 365 project. I probably always pick the wrong one.

    The photos below are a good example. I chose the top one, but now I'm beginning to think that's the worst of the three.

    Let me know which one you'd have chosen. Also, tell me if you even think any of them are actually any good. Positive or negative feedback is always welcome; I'll just be happy to get comments that aren't from spambots.

  • Mar 29, 2011

    78/365: Sick!

    Day 78 was a success, I'd say, and produced one of my favourites so far. This was taken just a short walk from my house at Reddicth Skate & BMX park. There were loads of people there, and I got so many almost great photos of them mid-jump (including a few of them upside down, mid-flip), but they were all moving so quickly that they weren't completely in frame.

    Honorable mention goes to the photo below that would have possibly been my photo for this day, except for the fact that I found it on the camera about a week too late.

    Some of the guys wanted to see what pictures I took and they reliably informed me that they're sick photos. That means they liked them.

    I'm sure I'll be heading back there a couple more times before the project is up.

  • Mar 2, 2011

    57/365: A genuine original

    On day 57 (Saturday to you) I went for a trip to the village of Tanworth-in-Arden to take some photos and visit the grave of - and what appears to be becoming a small shrine to - the excellent Nick Drake. Ever since I was introduced to his music the album Bryter Layter has been one of my favourites and it's truly sad that he died before getting the recognition he deserved.

    The back of his gravestone features a couple of lines of his lyrics.

    The sign for Tanworth-in-Arden post office.

  • Feb 10, 2011

    greenandlonely 2.0

    I'd been threatening it for quite a while. So, during the Christmas break, with Nick Drake, Battles and Sigur Ros for company and Dr. Pepper for fuel, I finally re-designed the site.

    I kind of just copied my favourite bits from a number of Wordpress sites and themes I'd seen, so if you think you recognise any parts of it, you're probably right.

    Let me know what you think. It's not 100% done, but I decided that putting incomplete work live would act as the initiative I need in order to get it finished. That being said, I'm quite pleased it's got this far; the original design was only supposed to be there temporarily and it lasted for the best part of 2 years!

  • Jan 22, 2011

    18/365: "I wanna be able to see my face in it"

    This is the first daily photo taken with my new DSLR. I'd originally bought a second-hand Nikon D70s, but when it arrived broken and completely unusable I decided to return that and go for a brand new D3100. In short, it's ace, although I haven't worked out how to get the best out of it yet. For now at least, hopefully these photos will be slightly better quality.

    By the way, if anyone wants to buy me a new lens or two I'll be your friend forever. Or a new bag. Anything, I'm not fussy.

    1/365: Guitar shop

  • Dec 24, 2010

    Yule blog

    I lost interest in this site quite a while ago, but I'm now back in a bit of a blogging mood so you can expect much more from me in 2011. This is mainly down to my deciding to embark on a 1-photo-a-day project type thing. I'll be posting all 365 photos here, so even if I don't write a lot, at least I'll be posting.

    Speaking of photos...

    I really wish I was a better photographer. I plan on getting better, which will involve reading interesting photography books (suggestions welcome) and hopefully buying a better camera (although with a move to Leamington Spa planned for some time in the next 18 months I can't really see that happening).

    Happy Jesus party!

  • Jul 29, 2009

    OK to die now

    My organ donor card has arrived in the post. I have no idea why I wasn't already a registered donor, I'd just never really thought about it before. Now I have been thinking about it, to me, organ donation seems to be something people should have to opt out of, rather than the other way round.

    If you feel the same, this is how to sign yourself up.

  • Jul 3, 2009

    Focus, idiot

    For the last few months I've found that, if left to my own devices, I haven't been able to concentrate on anything for long enough to actually get it done. No matter how much I want to achieve, within five minutes of starting I'll completely lose concentration and my mind will wander to other, much less important activities like checking email or watching crap on YouTube.

    The worst thing is I don't exactly know why I do that, especially when there's so much I'd love to learn and experience. All I know is that my list of to-dos seems so long that to even arrange it into some sort of practical order is starting to look like a colossal task in itself. Of course, the longer I sit and moan about it, etc, etc.

    Anyway, despite that, you might have noticed I've made a few additions to the site footer in the shape of a Twitter box and my Flickr photostream feed. Next up: styling and turning on comments. I'll be starting that next week, so expect it sometime in 2015.

  • Mar 15, 2009

    Warrenmusic

    I love playing the guitar, but most of the time I need all the help I can get when it comes to learning new songs. Tabs are quite good, although I sometimes find them quite difficult to follow. It doesn't help that most of the tabs I find are seldom correct.

    That's why I love this man. He films himself teaching near perfect renditions of Radiohead songs and posts the videos on YouTube for lazy/tab-illiterate people like me to learn. They're ideal for me because I pretty much only want to play Radiohead songs, and I'm always much better at learning something when it's demonstrated to me a couple of hundred times.

    I've recently been trying to tackle Jigsaw:

  • Mar 8, 2009

    We're going to Kenya!

    After several weeks and what seemed like tonnes of holiday brochures, we finally booked our holiday today. At the end of September, Steph and I fly to Kenya for two weeks! We're staying in a hotel on the coast for a couple of days, going on a 3 night safari in the Tsavo East & Tsavo West National Parks, then it's back to the hotel for the rest of the holiday. I think it's fair to say I haven't been this excited in years.

  • Mar 3, 2009

    Hello!

    I was a bit unhappy about being one of the only Web developers who didn't have an up-to-date website, so... tah-dah! Welcome, friend(s). Have a look around if you want, although I'm afraid you won't find much at the moment. Sorry for the lack of content right now but I'll slowly start adding new stuff and a few bells and whistles here and there, just as soon as I decide exactly what I want to do with the site.
